Abstract: This paper reviews recent advancements in the theoretical understanding of inhomogeneous and anisotropic turbulence, a complex phenomenon prevalent in various natural and engineered systems. By integrating quasi-linear approaches and advanced statistical methods, researchers have made significant strides in modeling the intricate dynamics of turbulent flows. These developments offer deeper insights into the energy transfer mechanisms and structural characteristics of turbulence, paving the way for more accurate predictions and control strategies in applications ranging from atmospheric science to aerospace engineering.
